awd_abstract_narration: This award from the Chemistry Research Instrumentation and Facilities Program will assist the  Department of Chemistry at University of Minnesota at Duluth acquire a 300 MHz NMR  Spectrometer. This equipment will enhance research in a number of areas including the  following: (1) Creation of New Carbon-Carbon Bonds, (2) Halocyclopropyl Ether Fragmentation  Applied to the Development of a Substituted Acrolein Anion Synthon, (3) Chemistry of  Polyvalent Iodine, and (4) The Regiochemistry of the Hydroboration of 1-Aryl-1-Propenes.    Nuclear Magnetic Resonance (NMR) spectroscopy is the most powerful tool available to  chemists for the elucidation of the structure of molecules. It is used to identify unknown  substances, characterize specific arrangements of atoms within molecules, and to study the  dynamics of interactions between molecules in solution. Access to state-of-the-art NMR  spectrometry is essential to chemists who are carrying out frontier research. The results from  these NMR studies are useful in the areas such as polymers, catalysis, and in biology.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences
